HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 16, 1926.

MORE ON CUTS
Such a large and entirely favorable body of comment hits
been aroused by our recent editorial, "Unlimited Cuts," that
we feel that the matter should be brought again to the attention of the Univeristy authorities. When student opinion is
strongly behind a proposal for remodeling a rule or regulation,
it cannot be very well ignored; the powers that be should take
action one way or the other upon the scheme.
The NEWS-LETTER'S reasons for advocating unlimited cuts
for the two upper classes are, we believe, logical, and the idea
is certainly not of a radical nature. By the time a man has
entered the Junior year he should be fairly well matured; at
least he should be given more freedom than he has previously
had. It is merely training for the greater freedom of the workaday world. Now, if a student cannot sufficiently control his
impulse to loaf to attend classes regularly, even though he has
no club over his head to make him do so, it seems to us that he
is unfit for university work, and his possible failure through
lack of attendance would be small loss. On the other hand, a
bright and energetic student can easily get the work of an average course done through outside reading, for, to quote our
previous editorial, "nine-tenths of all lectures are merely rehashes of matters which are treated fully in the texts." This
additional freedom would give the enterprising student fuller
opportunities for study in whatever subject he happens to be
particularly interested.
It is to be noted further that the more forceful men of the
faculty have no difficulty, even when they do not have the roll
taken, in keeping up a large attendance. Witness the huge registration in certain elective courses. If a professor fears unlimited cuts it is not to be supposed that he is altruisticly
attentive to the supposed welfare of the students; it is more
likely that he apprehends a marked decline in attendance upon
his lectures,—which would brand him as another "dry as dust."
We beieve that unlimited cuts would be quite in accordance with the Hopkins' ideal of freedom for students within
the bounds of decency. Consequently, we call our proposal to
the attention of the Student Council, and ask that they consider the question. If they act favorably upon the plan, they
should take it up with the Dean; if they do not, the . NEWSLETTER, in spite of the obvious sentiment of the students, is
willing to let the matter drop.

LANIER MEMORIAL
The letter of Dr. Knight Dunlap, advocating a permanent
and substantial memorial to Sidney Lanier, is very much to the
point. However, the NEWS-LETTER favors a little different type
of memorial.
Instead of a building, which would be both costly and not
entirely necessary, we propose that a Lanier Book Fund, a
Lanier Professorship of American Literature, or- a•Lanier Room
be established. The second of these would be very expensive; at
least two hundred thousand dollars would be required for endowment; the last would alone be inadequate; so we are forced
to recommend the Book Fund as th most practical plan.
The *ay in which,the Gilman Book Fund is working would
seem to be sufficient indication that a Lanier Fund would provide a real memorial to the poet.

"Progress through irrational and astounding blunders,
whose outrageousness bedwarfs the wildest cliches of romance,
was what Kennaston found everywhere.
"Just as men's lives seem like many infinitesimal threads
woven into the pattern of human destiny, so . . . the existence
of mankind upon the earth was but an incident in the unending
struggle of life to find a home in the universe. Human inhabitancy was not even a very important phase in this world's
history, perhaps; a scant score or so of centuries ago there had
been no life on earth, and by and by the planet would be a
silent, naked, frozeri clod. Would this sphere have served its
real purpose of being, by having afforded foothold to life for a
few years? For life was not a part of the universe at all perhaps, but rather, an intruder into the cosmic machinery, which
moved along without any consideration of life's needs.
"Toward what end did life aspire? . . . an intruder, a
temporary visitor, in the big, moving, soulless mechanism of
earth and water and planets and suns and interlocking solar
systems. The planet was so elaborately constructed . . . and
the body that housed Felix Kennaston was so intricately
wrought with tiny bones and veins and sinews . . . that it
seemed unreasonable to suppose this much cunning mechanism
had been set agoing aimlessly; and so he had often wondered
if he was not perhaps expected to devote these years to some
intelligible purpose?
"But Kennaston could find little to attract him in any
theory of the universe based on direct revelation from heaven.
Conceding that divinity had actually stated so-and-so, from
Sinai or Delphi or Mecca, and had been reported without miscomprehension or error, there was no particular reason for
believing that divinity had spoken veraciously; and, indeed, all
available analogues went to show that nothing in nature dealt
with its inferiors candidly.
"To exercise for an allotted period divinely recommended
qualities known as virtues, and to be rewarded therefor, by an
immortal score-keeper, appeared a rather childish performance
all around.
"Under all theocracies the run of men proved much the
same . . . Ritualistic worship everywhere seemed to be of the
nature of a Conscious outing; of a conscious departure from
everyday life; it was generally felt that well-balanced people
would not permit such jaunts to interfere with their business:
matters or home-ties; but there was no doubt men .did not like
to live without religion and religion's promise of a less trivial
and more ordered and symmetrical existence—tomorrow . . .
Today alone was real . . . and it was in the insignificance of
this moment,,precisely, that religious persons must believe . . .
That was why all art, which strove to make the sensations of
a moment soul-satisfying, was dimly felt to be,irreligious. For
art preformed what religion only promised.
-Yet that today was only a dull overture to tomorrow
seemed in mankind an instinctive belief .. . Felix Kennaston
reflected that, through accident's signal favor, he had done all
he had at any time very earnestly wanted to do; and that the

An Excellent Suggestion
Editor of the News-Letters
Sir:
A memorial to the dead need
not be a dead memorial. The
real memorial to Gilman is not
the central chamber in which are
collected the trappings of his
academic success, as were the im
penal etceteras of Tutankamen
in his royal tomb; it is the larger
building in which centers the intellectual vitality of the University. So, the fittest memorial to
Lanier would be a building in
which University activities appropriate in character to Lanier's
work and interests would continually be carried on.
One of the vital needs of the
University is for an auditorium,
adequate in size and -plan to
house the official public assemblages, the public lectures which
have long been a part of the University's public relations, the
concerts, recitals, and larger
Nothing
dramatic
offerings.
would be more appropriate than
that this auditorium should be
named Lanier Hall, and should
constitute a living memorial to
the man.
It is not improbable that the
project of such a building would
appeal in a peculiar- way to the
people.of Baltimore, since Lanier
Hall would mean very much to
the literary and artistic life of
the city, as well as to Hopkins.

story-books . . . Then it occurred to him that, in reality, he
had always been shuffling through today—somehow and anyhow—in the belief that tomorrow the life of Felix Kennaston
would be converted into a romance like those in story-books
... Men everywhere were living as he had lived . . . People
progressed from the kindergarten to the cemetery assuming
that their emotion at every crisis was what the books taught
them was, the appropriate emotion, and without noticing that
it was in reality something quite different . . . Living might
become symmetrical, well-plotted, coherent, and as rational as
living was in books.
"Then he perceived that there was no such thing as symmetry in inanimate nature... It needed only a glance toward
the sky the first clear night to show .that there was no patternwork in the arfangement of the stars. Nor were the planets
moving around the sun at speeds or distances which bore any
conceivable relation to one another. It was all at loose ends.
He wondered how he could possibly have been misled by pulpit
platitudes into likening this circumambient anarchy to mechanism . . . And on earth there was no balancing in the distribution of earth and water . . . It was all at loose ends, except—
bewilderingly—when water froze . . . the ice-crystals were
arranged in perfect and very elaborate patterns . . . unreason
made sure that even here the universe should run askew to any
conceivable "design" and lose even the coherency of being everywhere irregular.
"Living creatures represented life's groping toward that
goal (order, symmetry, balance) . . . Life strove toward the
creation of art. That was all life cared about . .. Kennaston
insisted that living things and inanimate nature had none of
the earmarks of being by the same author."
"It was this course of speculation which converted Kennaston to an abiding faith in Christianity . . . To believe this
inconsiderable planet the peculiar center of God's efforts and
attention had for a long while strained Kennaston's credulity;
The thing was so woefully out of proportion when you considered earth's relative value in the universe. But now Felix
Rennaston comprehended that in the insensate universe there
was no proportion."

HERE'S an old philosophy that Progress develops through opposition.
The scheme of things probably demands opponents to all great progressive
movements.

49

Columbus was pointed to as insane.
Robert Fulton was scoffed at.
Bell peddled his telephone.
Westinghouse faced despair with his air brake.
Gilman, Remsen, Gildersleeve, Rowland and Brooks kept Hopkins alive through a
period of poverty and starvation.
And did more—remained true to their great vision—steered clear of popular acclaims
rocks and shoals and built a great University.
A University in fact as well as in name that has taken its place among those in the
foreranks of the world.

Did they face opposition? They did!

Isn't it a fact that one man in research at Hopkins unlocking
the secret of cancer is more important than a hundred allAmerican football stars?

Did they face despair? They did!
Did they make their sacrifices? They did!
Daniel Gilman passed into the Great Beyond with but a
glimpse of the Promised Land as his reward.
Remsen forewent his great love of research in his chosen
field to "carry on" where Gilman left off.
_

Rowland--broken in health early in life, died with other
great scientific truths just within his reach.
Brooks knew the heartaches of facing the truths in a virgin
realm without means or men to explore.
They one and all were truth bearers. They one and all were
handicapped, opposed, criticised.
But they one and all contributed individually and collectively to the sum total of human progress far beyond even
their conception.

Isn't it a fact that one man in research at Hopkins solving
the secret of converting the sea's great energy into usable
power is more important than a hundred "class-rushes"
or a score of cotillions?
Isn't it a fact that one, five or fifty men investigating World
problems, developing statesmanship and solving the great
questions of International Relations; eliminating war and
making for unbroken World Peace will loom larger in the
acclaim of humanity than ten thousand Hopkins undergraduates with no definite purpose other than self-service?
In the new scheme of things Hopkins' Alumni and students
sacrifice nothing but the relatively superficial. But they gain
a position and prestige that as years go on will increase a
hundred-fold.

If the history of Hopkins were to be written in parts One
and Two, one might well say these great men and their
associates completed Part One in a blaze of glory.

There's an old saying that "What we're not up on, we're
down on."

Or are you going to tell a story of mental giants using their
knowledge to harness great latent unknown forces to better
serve mankind- -

Let's not oppose our today's Gilmans, Gildersleeves, Rowlands, Remsens, Oslers and Brookses.

The men opposing the new Hopkins era of Freshman-Sophomore elimination and a higher development of graduate and
Part Two is still being written!
research work are only "down on it" because they have not
What are You going to write?
had the opportunity to get "up on" this tremendously big
--World
-Reaching idea.
Are you going to write in term's of athletic prowess?

To make understandable fundamental natural, economic,
and human laws whose understanding and application will
raise World standards and eliminate destruction and waste.

Let's get back of Goodnow, Welch, Ames, Berry, Abel,
Jennings, Wilmer, Wood, Hollander arid their colleagues.
They are Truth Bearers. We can handicap them but their
truth will prevail.

be

A conference of "The Christian
Way of Life" will be held at
Western Maryland College, Westminster, Md., from February 2628. It will be. conducted under
the auspices of the Council of
Student Christian Association of
Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia. This organization includes all the Y. M. C. A.
and Y. W. C. A. groups, in every
college in this section, and all the
other groups devoted to Christian
service.
Distinguished Speakers

The conference will be featured
by addresses from Hon. J. Stitt
Wilson and F. N. Seerley, M. D.
The former, who was mayor of
Berkeley, California, has given
his entire time since '1919 to
speaking to students in all sections of the country. His rich
background of experience in social• and religious work both in
the United States and Europe,
plus a unique personality, make
him one of the foremost speakers
at Student Conferences in the
United States. Dr. Seerley, Dean
of the Y. M. C. A. College at
Springfield, Mass., has the reputation of being the, best man
qualified to deal with the "Social
Relations of Men and Women"
now available in the countr.,-.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., FEBRUARY 16, 1926.

MORE ON CUTS
Such a large and entirely favorable body of comment hits
been aroused by our recent editorial, "Unlimited Cuts," that
we feel that the matter should be brought again to the attention of the Univeristy authorities. When student opinion is
strongly behind a proposal for remodeling a rule or regulation,
it cannot be very well ignored; the powers that be should take
action one way or the other upon the scheme.
The NEWS-LETTER'S reasons for advocating unlimited cuts
for the two upper classes are, we believe, logical, and the idea
is certainly not of a radical nature. By the time a man has
entered the Junior year he should be fairly well matured; at
least he should be given more freedom than he has previously
had. It is merely training for the greater freedom of the workaday world. Now, if a student cannot sufficiently control his
impulse to loaf to attend classes regularly, even though he has
no club over his head to make him do so, it seems to us that he
is unfit for university work, and his possible failure through
lack of attendance would be small loss. On the other hand, a
bright and energetic student can easily get the work of an average course done through outside reading, for, to quote our
previous editorial, "nine-tenths of all lectures are merely rehashes of matters which are treated fully in the texts." This
additional freedom would give the enterprising student fuller
opportunities for study in whatever subject he happens to be
particularly interested.
It is to be noted further that the more forceful men of the
faculty have no difficulty, even when they do not have the roll
taken, in keeping up a large attendance. Witness the huge registration in certain elective courses. If a professor fears unlimited cuts it is not to be supposed that he is altruisticly
attentive to the supposed welfare of the students; it is more
likely that he apprehends a marked decline in attendance upon
his lectures,—which would brand him as another "dry as dust."
We beieve that unlimited cuts would be quite in accordance with the Hopkins' ideal of freedom for students within
the bounds of decency. Consequently, we call our proposal to
the attention of the Student Council, and ask that they consider the question. If they act favorably upon the plan, they
should take it up with the Dean; if they do not, the . NEWSLETTER, in spite of the obvious sentiment of the students, is
willing to let the matter drop.

LANIER MEMORIAL
The letter of Dr. Knight Dunlap, advocating a permanent
and substantial memorial to Sidney Lanier, is very much to the
point. However, the NEWS-LETTER favors a little different type
of memorial.
Instead of a building, which would be both costly and not
entirely necessary, we propose that a Lanier Book Fund, a
Lanier Professorship of American Literature, or- a•Lanier Room
be established. The second of these would be very expensive; at
least two hundred thousand dollars would be required for endowment; the last would alone be inadequate; so we are forced
to recommend the Book Fund as th most practical plan.
The *ay in which,the Gilman Book Fund is working would
seem to be sufficient indication that a Lanier Fund would provide a real memorial to the poet.

"Progress through irrational and astounding blunders,
whose outrageousness bedwarfs the wildest cliches of romance,
was what Kennaston found everywhere.
"Just as men's lives seem like many infinitesimal threads
woven into the pattern of human destiny, so . . . the existence
of mankind upon the earth was but an incident in the unending
struggle of life to find a home in the universe. Human inhabitancy was not even a very important phase in this world's
history, perhaps; a scant score or so of centuries ago there had
been no life on earth, and by and by the planet would be a
silent, naked, frozeri clod. Would this sphere have served its
real purpose of being, by having afforded foothold to life for a
few years? For life was not a part of the universe at all perhaps, but rather, an intruder into the cosmic machinery, which
moved along without any consideration of life's needs.
"Toward what end did life aspire? . . . an intruder, a
temporary visitor, in the big, moving, soulless mechanism of
earth and water and planets and suns and interlocking solar
systems. The planet was so elaborately constructed . . . and
the body that housed Felix Kennaston was so intricately
wrought with tiny bones and veins and sinews . . . that it
seemed unreasonable to suppose this much cunning mechanism
had been set agoing aimlessly; and so he had often wondered
if he was not perhaps expected to devote these years to some
intelligible purpose?
"But Kennaston could find little to attract him in any
theory of the universe based on direct revelation from heaven.
Conceding that divinity had actually stated so-and-so, from
Sinai or Delphi or Mecca, and had been reported without miscomprehension or error, there was no particular reason for
believing that divinity had spoken veraciously; and, indeed, all
available analogues went to show that nothing in nature dealt
with its inferiors candidly.
"To exercise for an allotted period divinely recommended
qualities known as virtues, and to be rewarded therefor, by an
immortal score-keeper, appeared a rather childish performance
all around.
"Under all theocracies the run of men proved much the
same . . . Ritualistic worship everywhere seemed to be of the
nature of a Conscious outing; of a conscious departure from
everyday life; it was generally felt that well-balanced people
would not permit such jaunts to interfere with their business:
matters or home-ties; but there was no doubt men .did not like
to live without religion and religion's promise of a less trivial
and more ordered and symmetrical existence—tomorrow . . .
Today alone was real . . . and it was in the insignificance of
this moment,,precisely, that religious persons must believe . . .
That was why all art, which strove to make the sensations of
a moment soul-satisfying, was dimly felt to be,irreligious. For
art preformed what religion only promised.
-Yet that today was only a dull overture to tomorrow
seemed in mankind an instinctive belief .. . Felix Kennaston

he had at any time very earnestly wanted to do; and that the

An Excellent Suggestion
Editor of the News-Letters
Sir:
A memorial to the dead need
not be a dead memorial. The
real memorial to Gilman is not
the central chamber in which are
collected the trappings of his
academic success, as were the im
penal etceteras of Tutankamen
in his royal tomb; it is the larger
building in which centers the intellectual vitality of the University. So, the fittest memorial to
Lanier would be a building in
which University activities appropriate in character to Lanier's
work and interests would continually be carried on.
One of the vital needs of the
University is for an auditorium,
adequate in size and -plan to
house the official public assemblages, the public lectures which
have long been a part of the University's public relations, the
concerts, recitals, and larger
Nothing
dramatic
offerings.
would be more appropriate than
that this auditorium should be
named Lanier Hall, and should
constitute a living memorial to
the man.
It is not improbable that the
project of such a building would
appeal in a peculiar- way to the
people.of Baltimore, since Lanier
Hall would mean very much to
the literary and artistic life of
the city, as well as to Hopkins.

had always been shuffling through today—somehow and anyhow—in the belief that tomorrow the life of Felix Kennaston
would be converted into a romance like those in story-books
... Men everywhere were living as he had lived . . . People

"Then he perceived that there was no such thing as symmetry in inanimate nature... It needed only a glance toward
the sky the first clear night to show .that there was no patternwork in the arfangement of the stars. Nor were the planets
moving around the sun at speeds or distances which bore any
conceivable relation to one another. It was all at loose ends.
He wondered how he could possibly have been misled by pulpit
platitudes into likening this circumambient anarchy to mechanism . . . And on earth there was no balancing in the distribution of earth and water . . . It was all at loose ends, except—
bewilderingly—when water froze . . . the ice-crystals were
arranged in perfect and very elaborate patterns . . . unreason
made sure that even here the universe should run askew to any
conceivable "design" and lose even the coherency of being everywhere irregular.
"Living creatures represented life's groping toward that
goal (order, symmetry, balance) . . . Life strove toward the
creation of art. That was all life cared about . .. Kennaston
insisted that living things and inanimate nature had none of
the earmarks of being by the same author."
"It was this course of speculation which converted Kennaston to an abiding faith in Christianity . . . To believe this
inconsiderable planet the peculiar center of God's efforts and
attention had for a long while strained Kennaston's credulity;
The thing was so woefully out of proportion when you considered earth's relative value in the universe. But now Felix
Rennaston comprehended that in the insensate universe there
was no proportion."

THE TRUTH BEARER
You

But--His Truth Will Prevail!

HERE'S an old philosophy that Progress develops through opposition.
The scheme of things probably demands opponents to all great progressive
movements.

49
0
4;0};M
;1

Columbus was pointed to as insane.
Robert Fulton was scoffed at.
Bell peddled his telephone.
Westinghouse faced despair with his air brake.
Gilman, Remsen, Gildersleeve, Rowland and Brooks kept Hopkins alive through a
period of poverty and starvation.
And did more—remained true to their great vision—steered clear of popular acclaims
rocks and shoals and built a great University.
A University in fact as well as in name that has taken its place among those in the
foreranks of the world.

Did they face opposition? They did!

Isn't it a fact that one man in research at Hopkins unlocking
the secret of cancer is more important than a hundred allAmerican football stars?

Did they face despair? They did!
Did they make their sacrifices? They did!
Daniel Gilman passed into the Great Beyond with but a
glimpse of the Promised Land as his reward.
Remsen forewent his great love of research in his chosen
field to "carry on" where Gilman left off.
_

Rowland--broken in health early in life, died with other
great scientific truths just within his reach.
Brooks knew the heartaches of facing the truths in a virgin
realm without means or men to explore.
They one and all were truth bearers. They one and all were
handicapped, opposed, criticised.
But they one and all contributed individually and collectively to the sum total of human progress far beyond even
their conception.

Isn't it a fact that one man in research at Hopkins solving
the secret of converting the sea's great energy into usable
power is more important than a hundred "class-rushes"
or a score of cotillions?
Isn't it a fact that one, five or fifty men investigating World
problems, developing statesmanship and solving the great
questions of International Relations; eliminating war and
making for unbroken World Peace will loom larger in the
acclaim of humanity than ten thousand Hopkins undergraduates with no definite purpose other than self-service?
In the new scheme of things Hopkins' Alumni and students
sacrifice nothing but the relatively superficial. But they gain
a position and prestige that as years go on will increase a
hundred-fold.

If the history of Hopkins were to be written in parts One
and Two, one might well say these great men and their
associates completed Part One in a blaze of glory.

There's an old saying that "What we're not up on, we're
down on."

Or are you going to tell a story of mental giants using their
knowledge to harness great latent unknown forces to better
serve mankind- -

Let's not oppose our today's Gilmans, Gildersleeves, Rowlands, Remsens, Oslers and Brookses.

The men opposing the new Hopkins era of Freshman-Sophomore elimination and a higher development of graduate and
Part Two is still being written!
research work are only "down on it" because they have not
What are You going to write?
had the opportunity to get "up on" this tremendously big
--World
-Reaching idea.
Are you going to write in term's of athletic prowess?

To make understandable fundamental natural, economic,
and human laws whose understanding and application will
raise World standards and eliminate destruction and waste.

Let's get back of Goodnow, Welch, Ames, Berry, Abel,
Jennings, Wilmer, Wood, Hollander arid their colleagues.
They are Truth Bearers. We can handicap them but their
truth will prevail.

CHRISTIAN CONFERENCE
TO BE ATTENDED
BY Y. M. C. A.
Western Maryland College to
Scene of Discussions on
"Way of Life."

be

A conference of "The Christian
Way of Life" will be held at
Western Maryland College, Westminster, Md., from February 2628. It will be. conducted under
the auspices of the Council of
Student Christian Association of
Maryland, Delaware and the District of Columbia. This organization includes all the Y. M. C. A.
and Y. W. C. A. groups, in every
college in this section, and all the
other groups devoted to Christian
service.
Distinguished Speakers

The conference will be featured
by addresses from Hon. J. Stitt
Wilson and F. N. Seerley, M. D.
The former, who was mayor of
Berkeley, California, has given
his entire time since '1919 to
speaking to students in all sections of the country. His rich
background of experience in social• and religious work both in
the United States and Europe,
plus a unique personality, make
him one of the foremost speakers
at Student Conferences in the
United States. Dr. Seerley, Dean
of the Y. M. C. A. College at
Springfield, Mass., has the reputation of being the, best man
qualified to deal with the "Social
Relations of Men and Women"
now available in the countr.,-.
